problem.script:
from __future__ import division import math
r1 = random.randrange(40000000000, 60000000000, 1000000000) r1km = r1/1000 r2 = random.randrange(100000000000, 150000000000, 1000000000) r2km = r2/1000
msun = random.randrange(10,30,1) * 10 ** 29 mcloud = random.randrange(50,90,1) * 10 ** 27 G = 6.67 * 10 ** (-11)
t1 = math.sqrt( (4*math.pi**2) / (G*msun) * r1**3 ) t1days = round(t1 / (3600*24), 2) t2 = math.sqrt( (4*math.pi**2) / (G*(msun+mcloud)) * r2**3 ) t2days = round(t2 / (3600*24), 2)
problem.p: A young sun has two planets. One planet is close to the sun, at a distance of $r1km kilometers. Its orbital period is $t1days days. Another is farther away, at $r2km km, with an orbital period of $t2days days.

This solar system also has a dust cloud. The solar wind and the formation of the inner planet have cleared the dust out from the center of the system, but a substantial amount of it still remains between the two planets. Use the information you have about the orbits of the planets to approximate the mass of the dust cloud.
